house.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a building that someone lives in, especially one that has more than one level and is intended to be used by one family
house.translation[0].definitions[0].note: move house British English (=leave your house and go to live in another one)
house.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Why don’t you all come over to our house for coffee?
house.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: all the people who live in a house
house.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: He gets up at six and disturbs the whole house.
house.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a large public building used for a particular purpose
house.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: used in the names of large buildings, especially offices
house.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: the BBC television studios at Broadcasting House
house.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a building used for a particular purpose
house.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a group of people who make the laws of a country
house.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The president will address both houses of Congress.
house.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a company, especially one involved in a particular area of business
house.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: the part of a theatre, cinema etc where people sit
house.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: The show has been playing to full houses.
The house lights went down and the music started.
house.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: the people who have come to watch a performance
house.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: The show has been playing to packed houses since it opened.
house.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: in some schools, one of the groups that children of different ages are divided into to compete against each other, for example in sports competitions
house.translation[0].definitions[10].def: an important family, especially a royal family
house.translation[0].note_box[0].section: live in a house
They live in a really big house in Hampstead.
buy a house
We bought this house when Liam was just a baby.
rent a house
While he was working in London, Ken rented a house in Fulham.
sell a house
We decided to sell the house and move back to Seattle.
put your house on the market
They put the house on the market and began looking for an apartment.
move into/out of a house
We’re moving into our new house next week.
build a house
They’re building a house on land overlooking Galway Bay.
put up a house
I think they’ve ruined the village by putting up these new houses.
renovate a house
He makes money by renovating old houses and selling them on.
decorate a house
If we’re going to decorate the house, let’s get professionals in.
do up a house
We’ve been doing up the house bit by bit since we first moved in.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + house
a private house
It was a residential neighborhood of private houses.
a rented house
She shares a rented house with three other students.
a council house
The rent rise is a blow to council house tenants.
a Georgian/Victorian/Edwardian etc house
They live in a lovely old Edwardian house with high ceilings.
house + NOUN
house prices
House prices have tripled over the last ten years.
a house owner
All house owners must pay council tax.
a house purchase
A solicitor can help you with the legal aspects of a house purchase.
house hunting
Have you had any success with your house hunting?
house.translation[0].note_box[1].section: house
a building that someone lives in, especially one that is intended for one family, person, or couple to live in
Annie and Rick have just bought their first house.
The price of houses is going up all the time.
detached house
a house that is not joined to another house
a detached four-bedroomed house
semi-detached house
a house that is joined to another house on one side
terraced house
one of a row of houses that are joined together
townhouse
one of a row of houses that are joined together. In British English, townhouse is often used about a large and impressive house in a fashionable area of a city
an 18th-century townhouse in Bath
cottage
a small house in the country – used especially about houses in the UK
a little cottage in the country
a thatched cottage (=with a roof made of straw)
bungalow
a small house that is all on one level
Bungalows are suitable for many elderly people.
country house
a large house in the countryside, especially one that is of historical interest
The hotel was originally an Edwardian country house.
mansion
a very large house
the family’s Beverly Hills mansion
mobile home
a type of house that can be pulled by a large vehicle and moved to another place
ranch house
a long narrow house that is all on one level
a California ranch house
duplex
a house that is divided into two separate homes
an apartment
apartment
a set of rooms where someone lives that is part of a house or bigger building. In British English, people usually say flat. Apartment is used about large and expensive flats, or in advertisements
His apartment is on the eighth floor.
In London, I shared a flat with some other students.
condominium
one apartment in a building with several apartments, owned by the people who live in them
a 10-unit condominium complex
a group of houses
development
a group of new houses or other buildings that are all planned and built together on the same piece of land
The site is to be used for a new housing development.
estate
an area where a large group of houses have all been built together at the same time
She grew up on a council estate in Leeds.
house.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to provide someone with a place to live
house.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The refugees are being housed in temporary accommodation.
house.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if a building, place, or container houses something, it is kept there
house.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: the plastic case that houses the batteries
The collection is currently housed in the British Museum.
house.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a company, especially one that produces books, lends money, or designs clothes
house.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: the French fashion house, Yves Saint Laurent
house.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: used in the names of some office buildings
house.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: the BBC television studios at Broadcasting House
house.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: if work is done in house, it is done in a company’s offices by the company’s own staff. If work is done out of house, it is done outside the offices by people who are not directly employed by the company
house.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: We used to handle our advertising in house.
house.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: to try to make your business more PROFITABLE by getting rid of parts of the business or staff that are making you lose money
house.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: They have been clearing house before the relaunch of the company.
house.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: provided free to a customer by a restaurant, bar etc
